cluster_relations.rel_desc: Adding approximately 0.7% chromium to low alloy C-Mo steels eliminates graphitization.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: addition of about 0.7% chromium; steels with up to 1% Mo

remarks: Material context (low alloy C-Mo steels with up to 1% Mo) added as qualifiers rather than as extra entities.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject reduces, suppresses, or eliminates the occurrence or progression of the object process or phenomenon under specified conditions.
args.justification: The relation describes chromium addition eliminating (preventing) graphitization in low alloy C-Mo steels. This is a clear case of causal inhibition of a metallurgical degradation process by an alloying element. Using the canonical predicate 'inhibits' generalizes beyond this specific case while preserving the inhibitory/preventive meaning. The relation class is therefore set to a process-level inhibition type under the broad causal group.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject reduces, suppresses, or eliminates the occurrence or progression of the object process or phenomenon under specified conditions.
executed_decisions.justification: The relation describes chromium addition eliminating (preventing) graphitization in low alloy C-Mo steels. This is a clear case of causal inhibition of a metallurgical degradation process by an alloying element. Using the canonical predicate 'inhibits' generalizes beyond this specific case while preserving the inhibitory/preventive meaning. The relation class is therefore set to a process-level inhibition type under the broad causal group.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine are both used in amine treating to remove H2S and CO2 from hydrocarbon streams, indicating they serve similar functional roles and can be alternatives to each other.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ApplicationContext: amine treating of hydrocarbon streams for H2S and CO2 removal

remarks: Relation created to capture that these two amine treating chemicals share the same described use; semantics are approximated as an alternative/substitute relation since no explicit comparison wording is given.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure and Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: listed as peer damage mechanism categories in the same section

remarks: Relation reflects document-level grouping rather than a causal or hierarchical dependency; direction is arbitrary and used only to encode co-membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness and High Temperature Corrosion are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: co-listed as damage mechanism categories

remarks: Relation mainly encodes co-membership in the same list; not implying any causal or structural dependency between the mechanisms.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: High Temperature Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Stress Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking Mechanisms

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: both are subsections under the same damage mechanisms section

remarks: Relation created to capture that both mechanisms are co-classified in the same document section; direction is arbitrary.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities can serve similar functional roles in a given application and may be used as alternatives or substitutes for one another under comparable conditions.
args.justification: The relation describes methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine serving similar roles in amine treating and being usable as alternatives. A canonical name emphasizing functional substitutability generalizes this to other cases. This is best modeled as a functional similarity/alternative association rather than composition or causality.
args.remark: Direction is not semantically strict; the canonical predicate should be treated as symmetric in downstream reasoning.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities are grouped or listed together within the same classification system, document section, or category, without implying causal, hierarchical, or structural dependence.
args.justification: All three relations have relation_name 'grouped_with' and rel_hint_type 'co-classification', with descriptions explicitly stating that the mechanisms are co-listed as peer sections in the same damage mechanism classification. A shared canonical predicate 'co_classified_with' captures this symmetric, document- or taxonomy-based grouping. This is a classification-based association rather than causality or composition.
args.remark: These edges represent document/taxonomy structure; they should be treated as symmetric and non-hierarchical.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities can serve similar functional roles in a given application and may be used as alternatives or substitutes for one another under comparable conditions.
executed_decisions.justification: The relation describes methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine serving similar roles in amine treating and being usable as alternatives. A canonical name emphasizing functional substitutability generalizes this to other cases. This is best modeled as a functional similarity/alternative association rather than composition or causality.
executed_decisions.remark: Direction is not semantically strict; the canonical predicate should be treated as symmetric in downstream reasoning.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities are grouped or listed together within the same classification system, document section, or category, without implying causal, hierarchical, or structural dependence.
executed_decisions.justification: All three relations have relation_name 'grouped_with' and rel_hint_type 'co-classification', with descriptions explicitly stating that the mechanisms are co-listed as peer sections in the same damage mechanism classification. A shared canonical predicate 'co_classified_with' captures this symmetric, document- or taxonomy-based grouping. This is a classification-based association rather than causality or composition.
executed_decisions.remark: These edges represent document/taxonomy structure; they should be treated as symmetric and non-hierarchical.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is one of the four categories of stainless steels listed.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

remarks: Although text just says 'duplex', entity is resolved as duplex stainless steel; relation captures the category membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is a subtype/category within the broader class of stainless steels.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific type, category, or subclass within the broader class represented by the object.
args.justification: Both relations describe a hierarchical taxonomic relationship between stainless steel and duplex stainless steel: one as a category membership and the other explicitly as a subtype. These are semantically equivalent as class–subclass relations, differing only in direction. Using the canonical predicate 'is_subtype_of' captures this taxonomic identity relation consistently across both instances.
args.remark: Directionality is opposite between the two instances, but the underlying taxonomic relation is the same; query logic can handle inverse traversal if needed.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific type, category, or subclass within the broader class represented by the object.
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe a hierarchical taxonomic relationship between stainless steel and duplex stainless steel: one as a category membership and the other explicitly as a subtype. These are semantically equivalent as class–subclass relations, differing only in direction. Using the canonical predicate 'is_subtype_of' captures this taxonomic identity relation consistently across both instances.
executed_decisions.remark: Directionality is opposite between the two instances, but the underlying taxonomic relation is the same; query logic can handle inverse traversal if needed.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Austenitic stainless steels are characterized by an austenitic metallurgical structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: AlloyScope: 300 Series stainless steels including Types 304, 304L, 304H, 309, 310, 316, 316L, 316H, 321, 321H, 347, and 347H

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steels have an austenitic component in their mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureType: mixed austenitic-ferritic

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steels have a ferritic component in their mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureType: mixed austenitic-ferritic

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Welds of austenitic stainless steels may exhibit a duplex-type (austenitic-ferritic) structure, linking them conceptually to duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: in welds of 300 Series stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MicrostructureContext: weld metal/heat-affected zone duplex (austenitic-ferritic) structure

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that welds of austenitic stainless steels can show a duplex (austenitic-ferritic) microstructure; semantic mapping to the duplex stainless steel family is approximate.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are categorized based on having an austenitic metallurgical structure at room temperature.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are categorized based on having a ferritic metallurgical structure at room temperature.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are categorized based on having a martensitic metallurgical structure at room temperature.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

  {
    "function": "set_rel_schema",

      ],
      "canonical_rel_name": "has_metallurgical_structure",
      "canonical_rel_desc": "Indicates that the subject alloy or steel class possesses the specified metallurgical or microstructural phase/structure under the given conditions (e.g., temperature, location, or processing state).",
      "rel_cls": "structure_relation",
      "rel_cls_group": "COMPOSITION",
      "justification": "All six relations describe a structural/microstructural phase present in a steel or alloy (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic components, including mixed duplex structures). The existing relation_name is already a good canonical predicate, so it is reused. They clearly form a single predicate family describing which metallurgical structure a material has, which fits a structure-oriented relation class grouped under broad compositional/structural characterization.",
      "remark": "This canonical predicate can be reused for any material-to-metallurgical-structure linkage, with qualifiers capturing temperature (e.g., room temperature) and context (weld metal, mixed duplex, etc.).",
      "confidence": 0.96
    }
  },
  {
    "function": "set_rel_schema",
    "args": {
      "relation_ids": [
        "RelR_96a7cdcaa41e"
      ],
      "canonical_rel_name": "microstructurally_related_to",
      "canonical_rel_desc": "Indicates that the subject material is microstructurally related to the object material, typically because it can exhibit a similar type of phase mixture or metallurgical structure under certain conditions.",
      "rel_cls": "structural_association_relation",
      "rel_cls_group": "ASSOCIATION",
      "justification": "This relation does not state that austenitic stainless steels are duplex stainless steels, but that their welds may exhibit a duplex-type (austenitic–ferritic) microstructure similar to duplex stainless steels. This is a looser structural association rather than direct structure possession or identity. A more specific canonical predicate 'microstructurally_related_to' captures this nuance better than a generic 'associated_with', while remaining consistent with the structural/microstructural context.",
      "remark": "Kept the original raw relation_name 'associated_with' as evidence but tightened the canonical predicate to reflect microstructural similarity and conditionality indicated by qualifiers (welds, may, duplex structure).",

    }

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject alloy or steel class possesses the specified metallurgical or microstructural phase/structure under the given conditions (e.g., temperature, location, or processing state).
args.justification: All six relations describe a structural/microstructural phase present in a steel or alloy (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic components, including mixed duplex structures). The existing relation_name is already a good canonical predicate, so it is reused. They clearly form a single predicate family describing which metallurgical structure a material has, which fits a structure-oriented relation class grouped under broad compositional/structural characterization.
args.remark: This canonical predicate can be reused for any material-to-metallurgical-structure linkage, with qualifiers capturing temperature (e.g., room temperature) and context (weld metal, mixed duplex, etc.).

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject material is microstructurally related to the object material, typically because it can exhibit a similar type of phase mixture or metallurgical structure under certain conditions.
args.justification: This relation does not state that austenitic stainless steels are duplex stainless steels, but that their welds may exhibit a duplex-type (austenitic–ferritic) microstructure similar to duplex stainless steels. This is a looser structural association rather than direct structure possession or identity. A more specific canonical predicate 'microstructurally_related_to' captures this nuance better than a generic 'associated_with', while remaining consistent with the structural/microstructural context.
args.remark: Kept the original raw relation_name 'associated_with' as evidence but tightened the canonical predicate to reflect microstructural similarity and conditionality indicated by qualifiers (welds, may, duplex structure).

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject alloy or steel class possesses the specified metallurgical or microstructural phase/structure under the given conditions (e.g., temperature, location, or processing state).
executed_decisions.justification: All six relations describe a structural/microstructural phase present in a steel or alloy (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic components, including mixed duplex structures). The existing relation_name is already a good canonical predicate, so it is reused. They clearly form a single predicate family describing which metallurgical structure a material has, which fits a structure-oriented relation class grouped under broad compositional/structural characterization.
executed_decisions.remark: This canonical predicate can be reused for any material-to-metallurgical-structure linkage, with qualifiers capturing temperature (e.g., room temperature) and context (weld metal, mixed duplex, etc.).

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject material is microstructurally related to the object material, typically because it can exhibit a similar type of phase mixture or metallurgical structure under certain conditions.
executed_decisions.justification: This relation does not state that austenitic stainless steels are duplex stainless steels, but that their welds may exhibit a duplex-type (austenitic–ferritic) microstructure similar to duplex stainless steels. This is a looser structural association rather than direct structure possession or identity. A more specific canonical predicate 'microstructurally_related_to' captures this nuance better than a generic 'associated_with', while remaining consistent with the structural/microstructural context.
executed_decisions.remark: Kept the original raw relation_name 'associated_with' as evidence but tightened the canonical predicate to reflect microstructural similarity and conditionality indicated by qualifiers (welds, may, duplex structure).

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of carbon steels after long-term operation, degrading their mechanical properties.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.CausalHint: that may cause a loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: mechanical property degradation

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of 0.5Mo steels during long-term high-temperature operation.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization corresponds to decomposition of carbide phases into graphite nodules, effectively producing graphite nodules in the steel.
remarks: Carbide phases are not an explicit entity; relation framed between graphitization and graphite nodules to preserve transformation context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A process or condition changes or modifies the microstructure of a material, potentially affecting its properties.
args.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of steels under long-term high-temperature operation. The existing relation_name is already a good reusable predicate, so it is adopted as the canonical_rel_name. These are structural-change relations, so rel_cls is set to 'structure_relation' and grouped under 'MODIFICATION' to reflect microstructural modification.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A process or agent generates or results in the formation of a product, phase, or feature.
args.justification: This relation states that graphitization leads to the formation of graphite nodules, i.e., a transformation where the process produces a microstructural product. The relation_name 'produces' is appropriate as the canonical predicate. It is classified as a transformation_relation and placed under the broad causal group, since the process causally produces the product.
args.remark: Although the underlying metallurgical detail involves carbide decomposition, the modeled relation between graphitization and graphite nodules is correctly captured as a production/formation relation.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: A process or condition changes or modifies the microstructure of a material, potentially affecting its properties.
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of steels under long-term high-temperature operation. The existing relation_name is already a good reusable predicate, so it is adopted as the canonical_rel_name. These are structural-change relations, so rel_cls is set to 'structure_relation' and grouped under 'MODIFICATION' to reflect microstructural modification.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: A process or agent generates or results in the formation of a product, phase, or feature.
executed_decisions.justification: This relation states that graphitization leads to the formation of graphite nodules, i.e., a transformation where the process produces a microstructural product. The relation_name 'produces' is appropriate as the canonical predicate. It is classified as a transformation_relation and placed under the broad causal group, since the process causally produces the product.
executed_decisions.remark: Although the underlying metallurgical detail involves carbide decomposition, the modeled relation between graphitization and graphite nodules is correctly captured as a production/formation relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The austenitic structure is normally found in 300 Series austenitic stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: AlloyScope: 300 Series stainless steels

remarks: Complements the alloy→structure relation by capturing where the structure is typically present.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ferritic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Redundant with the duplex→ferritic structural relation but captures the inverse perspective (where ferritic is found).

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Austenitic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Inverse perspective of the duplex→austenitic structural relation, included for coverage of where the austenitic phase is found.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC) is described as a cracking mechanism that occurs in steels, which plausibly includes low alloy steels as a subset.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: on different planes in the metal / steels; may connect to the metal surface
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: no externally applied stress is needed for formation of HIC
qualifiers.CausalHint: because of internal pressure resulting from the accumulation of hydrogen
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CrackMechanism: stepwise internal cracks that connect adjacent hydrogen blisters; LinkMechanism: transgranular plastic shear

remarks: Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization occurs in low alloy C-Mo steels containing up to 1% Mo.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ObservationContext: field or service experience

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules are present in carbon steels as products of carbide decomposition at elevated temperatures.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Origin: decomposition of carbide phases

remarks: Subjective mapping of the pronoun “these steels” to carbon steels; 0.5Mo steels are handled in a separate relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules can also occur in 0.5Mo steels under elevated temperature conditions.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Origin: carbide phase decomposition associated with graphitization

remarks: Moderate uncertainty because the pronoun could be read as all previously mentioned affected steels.

llm_raw:
[
  {
    "function": "set_rel_schema",
    "args": {
      "relation_ids": [
        "RelR_ccb0e0161188",
        "RelR_c426520a3c91",
        "RelR_7c9bc782fce9",
        "RelR_caa4eec09380",
        "RelR_704fe359a26f",
        "RelR_81f81efb1983",
        "RelR_c686532b051c"
      ],
      "canonical_rel_name": "occurs_in",
      "canonical_rel_desc": "Indicates that a microstructural phase, cracking mechanism, degradation process, or product feature is observed or present within a given material or alloy family under specified conditions.",
      "rel_cls": "material_occurrence_relation",
      "rel_cls_group": "SPATIALITY",
      "justification": "All relations use the predicate 'occurs_in' and describe the presence or occurrence of a structure, phase, cracking mechanism, or degradation product within a specific steel or alloy type (e.g., austenitic phase in stainless steels, ferritic phase in duplex, HIC in low alloy steel, graphitization and graphite nodules in susceptible steels). Despite differing subjects (structures, mechanisms, products), the semantic pattern is consistent: an entity is present or observed in a material context. A shared canonical name 'occurs_in' with a generalized description and a common class 'material_occurrence_relation' under the broad SPATIALITY group captures this pattern without overfitting to any single subtype.",
      "remark": "Cluster covers both microstructural phases and damage/degradation phenomena but all follow the same material-occurrence pattern; qualifiers retain specifics such as conditions and causal hints.",
      "confidence": 0.93
    }
  }
]

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a microstructural phase, cracking mechanism, degradation process, or product feature is observed or present within a given material or alloy family under specified conditions.
args.justification: All relations use the predicate 'occurs_in' and describe the presence or occurrence of a structure, phase, cracking mechanism, or degradation product within a specific steel or alloy type (e.g., austenitic phase in stainless steels, ferritic phase in duplex, HIC in low alloy steel, graphitization and graphite nodules in susceptible steels). Despite differing subjects (structures, mechanisms, products), the semantic pattern is consistent: an entity is present or observed in a material context. A shared canonical name 'occurs_in' with a generalized description and a common class 'material_occurrence_relation' under the broad SPATIALITY group captures this pattern without overfitting to any single subtype.
args.remark: Cluster covers both microstructural phases and damage/degradation phenomena but all follow the same material-occurrence pattern; qualifiers retain specifics such as conditions and causal hints.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a microstructural phase, cracking mechanism, degradation process, or product feature is observed or present within a given material or alloy family under specified conditions.
executed_decisions.justification: All relations use the predicate 'occurs_in' and describe the presence or occurrence of a structure, phase, cracking mechanism, or degradation product within a specific steel or alloy type (e.g., austenitic phase in stainless steels, ferritic phase in duplex, HIC in low alloy steel, graphitization and graphite nodules in susceptible steels). Despite differing subjects (structures, mechanisms, products), the semantic pattern is consistent: an entity is present or observed in a material context. A shared canonical name 'occurs_in' with a generalized description and a common class 'material_occurrence_relation' under the broad SPATIALITY group captures this pattern without overfitting to any single subtype.
executed_decisions.remark: Cluster covers both microstructural phases and damage/degradation phenomena but all follow the same material-occurrence pattern; qualifiers retain specifics such as conditions and causal hints.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels contain varying amounts of chromium as an alloying element.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CompositionContext: alloy content in stainless steels

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against oxidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Resistance is mediated via stainless steels; not direct chromium surface behavior, but captured as a causal contribution.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against sulfidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Again, resistance is via its role in stainless steels rather than isolated chromium behavior.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium contributes to resistance to general corrosion forms when used as an alloying element in stainless steels.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels; depending on the alloy content
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: general corrosion (other forms of corrosion)

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that chromium helps overall corrosion resistance; semantics slightly generalized.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject alloy contains the object as an intentional alloying element in its composition.
args.justification: This relation captures a compositional fact: stainless steel includes chromium as an alloying element. The existing relation_name already matches a good normalized predicate, so it is reused as the canonical_rel_name. The rel_cls is set to composition_relation and grouped under COMPOSITION because it describes what elements are present in the alloy.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject (typically an alloying element or component) causally contributes to or enhances the resistance of the material to the specified corrosion mechanism.
args.justification: All three relations describe chromium, when used as an alloying element in stainless steels, causally improving resistance to specific corrosion mechanisms (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion). They are semantically equivalent at the predicate level, differing only in the target corrosion mode. A unified canonical_rel_name 'enhances_resistance_to_corrosion' generalizes over these mechanisms. The class corrosion_resistance_relation and group CAUSALITY reflect that this is a causal effect on corrosion behavior, not mere association.
args.remark: Although the physical resistance is expressed at the stainless steel level, the modeled relation appropriately attributes the causal contribution to chromium as an alloying element.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject alloy contains the object as an intentional alloying element in its composition.
executed_decisions.justification: This relation captures a compositional fact: stainless steel includes chromium as an alloying element. The existing relation_name already matches a good normalized predicate, so it is reused as the canonical_rel_name. The rel_cls is set to composition_relation and grouped under COMPOSITION because it describes what elements are present in the alloy.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject (typically an alloying element or component) causally contributes to or enhances the resistance of the material to the specified corrosion mechanism.
executed_decisions.justification: All three relations describe chromium, when used as an alloying element in stainless steels, causally improving resistance to specific corrosion mechanisms (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion). They are semantically equivalent at the predicate level, differing only in the target corrosion mode. A unified canonical_rel_name 'enhances_resistance_to_corrosion' generalizes over these mechanisms. The class corrosion_resistance_relation and group CAUSALITY reflect that this is a causal effect on corrosion behavior, not mere association.
executed_decisions.remark: Although the physical resistance is expressed at the stainless steel level, the modeled relation appropriately attributes the causal contribution to chromium as an alloying element.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are resistant to oxidation due to their alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MechanismType: corrosion mechanism

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are resistant to sulfidation due to their alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MechanismType: corrosion mechanism

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels resist various forms of general corrosion, beyond just oxidation and sulfidation, depending on alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: other forms of corrosion beyond oxidation and sulfidation

remarks: Relation generalized from phrase 'other forms of corrosion' to entity 'general corrosion'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a material or alloy exhibits resistance to a specified corrosion mechanism or type of corrosion under given conditions.
args.justification: All three relation instances share the same subject (Stainless Steel), the same predicate wording ('resists' / 'are resistant to'), and the same semantic type (resistance to corrosion processes). The objects differ only in the specific corrosion mechanism (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion), which fits naturally as different targets of the same canonical predicate. A single canonical_rel_name 'resists_corrosion' generalizes this behavior without encoding specific mechanisms. The class 'corrosion_resistance_relation' captures that this is a performance/behavior relation between a material and a corrosion mechanism, and 'INTERACTION' is an appropriate broad group since it describes how the material interacts with (i.e., withstands) a degrading environment or mechanism.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a material or alloy exhibits resistance to a specified corrosion mechanism or type of corrosion under given conditions.
executed_decisions.justification: All three relation instances share the same subject (Stainless Steel), the same predicate wording ('resists' / 'are resistant to'), and the same semantic type (resistance to corrosion processes). The objects differ only in the specific corrosion mechanism (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion), which fits naturally as different targets of the same canonical predicate. A single canonical_rel_name 'resists_corrosion' generalizes this behavior without encoding specific mechanisms. The class 'corrosion_resistance_relation' captures that this is a performance/behavior relation between a material and a corrosion mechanism, and 'INTERACTION' is an appropriate broad group since it describes how the material interacts with (i.e., withstands) a degrading environment or mechanism.
